title: Introduction to CSS
subject: CSS
learning_objectives: Understand what CSS is and why it is used
Learn the history and versions of CSS
Understand the separation of structure (HTML) and style (CSS)
theory:
CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is the language we use to style an HTML document. CSS describes how HTML elements should be displayed on screen, paper, or in other media. 

Before CSS, all formatting (fonts, colors, backgrounds, alignments) had to be explicitly described in the HTML itself. This made HTML documents long, complex, and unmanageable. CSS solved this problem by removing the style formatting from the HTML page.

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking CSS is a programming language
common_mistakes.correction: CSS is a style sheet language used for describing the presentation of a document written in a markup language.
common_mistakes.example:
WRONG: 'I coded the logic in CSS.'
CORRECT: 'I styled the page using CSS.'

interview_questions.question: What does CSS stand for?
interview_questions.answer: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets.

interview_questions.question: Why is CSS called 'Cascading'?
interview_questions.answer: The term 'Cascading' refers to the priority scheme that determines which style rule applies if more than one rule matches a particular element. Styles can come from multiple sources (user agent, user, author), and the cascade determines the winner.

practice_problems.problem: Create a new CSS rule to make all <h2> tags red.

real_world_use_cases.description: Companies use CSS to ensure all their web pages strictly follow their brand color guidelines and typography.

exam_notes: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets.
CSS saves a lot of work by controlling the layout of multiple web pages all at once.
External stylesheets are stored in CSS files.
summary: CSS is the standard markup language for describing the presentation of Web pages. It allows developers to separate content from design, enabling complex layouts and responsive designs across different devices.
